funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: Chinese Embassy, Government Agency
title: China provides US$300,000 of humanitarian aid to Myanmar after flood (link to ID #49176)
description: On 3 August 2015, the Chinese Embassy to Myanmar provided the first batch of humanitarian aid to Myanmar's flood-hit regions, which covered 1,545 families in Kalay township in Sagaing Region. The second batch of aid was delivered on 4 August 2015 to 20,000 families in Sittway. Chinese Ambassador to Myanmar Hong Liang also dispatched another group of Chinese diplomats to carry out a rescue mission in central Magway Region within the same week. The total fund of the program for Rakhine State as well as Sagaing and Magway regions amounted to about US$300,000. A special family rescue package had been designed to provide the flood-stricken people with daily necessities. This aid includes 100 motorboats to be sent to flood-hit areas.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=ATDOMB0020150810eb8a00001&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020150804eb8400692&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020150803eb83008px&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020150803eb83006eq&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://reliefweb.int/report/myanmar/chinese-team-rescue-13-flood-victims-myanmar, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.cntv.cn/2015/08/16/VIDE1439706721555419.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://books.google.com/books?id=8XIzDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA217&lpg=PA217&dq=china+300,000+aid+flood+myanmar+2015&source=bl&ots=jWzadSXaXN&sig=h2tEY2n_cyv1TXh3jc_iBuhEGmM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzoOK37a3XAhVK5CYKHXpMDIYQ6AEIUTAH#v=onepage&q=china%20300%2C000%20aid%20flood%20myanmar%202015&f=false, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2015-08/05/content_21502953.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://reliefweb.int/report/myanmar/more-chinese-relief-aid-sent-myanmar-flood-victims, Media Report, including Wikileaks
donor_agencies: Chinese Embassy, Government Agency
contacts: Hong Liang, Chinese Ambassador to Myanmar (Chinese Embassy)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China's Yunnan Province provides 2.41 million yuan of humanitarian aid to Myanmar after flood (link to ID #49175)
description: On 7 August 2015, the provincial government of China's Yunnan province handed over relief aid worth 2.41 million yuan to the Myanmar side in Mandalay in response to severe flooding. The relief aid included 1,000 bags of rice, 1,000 units of tents, 500 boxes of milk powder, and 10,000 boxes of instant noodle. These supplies were shipped by 14 trucks via the border gate of Muse to Mandalay. This relief aid is in addition to the US$300,000 captured in project ID #49175.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020150807eb87006y5&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020150814eb8e006he&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://reliefweb.int/report/myanmar/chinese-team-rescue-13-flood-victims-myanmar, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.cntv.cn/2015/08/16/VIDE1439706721555419.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://books.google.com/books?id=8XIzDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA217&lpg=PA217&dq=china+300,000+aid+flood+myanmar+2015&source=bl&ots=jWzadSXaXN&sig=h2tEY2n_cyv1TXh3jc_iBuhEGmM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzoOK37a3XAhVK5CYKHXpMDIYQ6AEIUTAH#v=onepage&q=china%20300%2C000%20aid%20flood%20myanmar%202015&f=false, Other Academic (Working Paper, Dissertation); https://reliefweb.int/report/myanmar/more-chinese-relief-aid-sent-myanmar-flood-victims, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China sends US$1.6 million worth of motorized dinghies to Myanmar to help with flood rescue operations
description: On 17 August 2015, China flew US$1.6 million worth of motorized dinghies to Myanmar to help with rescue operations after severe flooding.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: People's Liberation Army (PLA), Government Agency
title: Chinese PLA delivers 10 million yuan worth of humanitarian aid to Myanmar after flooding
description: On 28 August 2015, two military aircraft from the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) arrived at Myanmar's Nay Pyi Taw International Airport with relief supplies for flood victims. The supplies include blankets, electric generators and tents to be used by Myanmar flood victims. Another batch of PLA aid supplies would be delivered by two other military aircraft later. The total worth of teh PLA supplies amounts to 10 million yuan.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020150828eb8s0038q&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020150806eb86001md&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.chinamil.com.cn/news-channels/china-military-news/2015-08/28/content_6654308.htm, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: China Communications Construction Co., Ltd. (CCCC), State-owned Company
title: Chinese Company builds bridge in Brunei for $204 million
description: In 2015, the China Harbour Engineering Company Limited (CHEC) and Brunei signed a $204 million contract for the construction of Pulau Muara Besar Bridge, Road and Utilities. The completed 2.7 km bridge will connect the mainland to the western shore of Pulau Muara Besar with a 2.925km main road. Along the road, there will be tele-communications lines, supporting electrical networks, and a water supply pipeline network. The project was awarded to a CHEC's subsidiary, China Communications Construction Company Limited (CCCC), will take 36 months to complete, and is scheduled to be finished by April 2018.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=AIWBOR0020150507eb5700009&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.china.org.cn/world/Off_the_Wire/2015-05/06/content_35505868.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://en.xfafinance.com/html/Companies/2017/355439.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://bn.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201504/20150400930876.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://bn.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201505/20150500964060.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China donates 1,160 sets of prefabricated houses to Myanmar flood victims
description: On 22 February 2016, the Chinese government donated 1,160 sets of prefabricated houses for Myanmar's flood victims. The donation was valued at about 30 million yuan. This donation was delivered ceremonially to the Myanmar side at Myanmar International Terminals Thilawa.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020160222ec2m005h9&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CAPTIM0020160223ec2n0000i&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China government provides about 30 million kyats and Huawei provides another K10 million humanitarian assistance to Myanmar flood victims
description: On 24 August 2016, China provided about 40 million kyats humanitarian assistance to Myanmar's flood victims. This aid was sent through the Myanmar ministry of social welfare, relief and resettlement. This aid was provided by the Chinese Embassy, State Power Investment Corporation and Huawei Myanmar. STAFF_NOTE: During Huawei officials' meeting with Myanmar’s H.E.Vice President, they discussed the company’s activities and role in Myanmar. CEO Zhang Liman said Huawei Myanmar contributed K10 million in the donation, K40 million (US$33,000), of the Chinese embassy in Myanmar to flood victims at the Ministry of Social Welfare, Relief and Resettlement. So deduct K 10 million from the total amount as corporate aid.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020160824ec8o00b9l&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.huawei.com/en-mm/news/mm-en/2016/9/huawei-officials-meet-myanmars-vice-president, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China donates electrical equipment to Myanmar flood-hit areas
description: On 25 March 2016, China donated 36 million yuan worth of electrical equipment to Myanmar flood-hit areas. The donated goods were handed over by Chinese ambassador Hong Liang to Myanmar Minister of Electric Power U Khin Maung Soe. The electrical equipment from eight Chinese companies was being transported from China in three batches and the current batch worth 5 million yuans was the first batch while the remaining batches would arrive in Mandalay and Nay Pyi Taw by April and June.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020160325ec3p007ep&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://eng.spic.com.cn/NewsCenter/CorporateNews/201605/t20160503_262376.htm, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
contacts: U Khin Maung Soe, Myanmar Minister of Electric Power; Hong Liang, Chinese Ambassador to Myanmar (Chinese Embassy)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China grants $1 million USD to open joint Mongolian molecular biology laboratory
description: On Feb. 22, 2016, a new joint molecular biology laboratory, located in the Armono Corporation building in Khan-Uul District, Mongolia was opened. The laboratory was built through the Mongolian Science Park Project, financed by a one million USD grant from the Chinese government and with 350,000 USD in support from the President of Mongolia. The laboratory enables independent genome, protein, and probiotic research, as well as the study of the nutritional content of food products.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AUBPOS0020160223ec2n00001&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://mn.china-embassy.org/eng/zmgx/t1342297.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://akipress.com/news:573127/, Media Report, including Wikileaks
contacts: L.Gantumur, Minister of Education, Culture, and Science; Xing Haiming, Chinese Ambassador to Mongolia

funding_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
title: Mongolian International Airport Highway
description: On May 6, 2016, construction of the first highway in Mongolia, linking the capital Ulaanbaatar and the new international airport in Khushig Valley, Tuv Province, officially commenced. According to the feasibility study, the 30.4 kilometer, two-way highway will have six lanes, and will be funded through a soft loan from the Exim Bank of China, the construction works will be executed by the China TIESIJU Civil Engineering Group. The highway is expected be commissioned in July 2018. STAFF_NOTE: Reported transaction amount ranges from $140 million to $500 million.
sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=AUBPOS0020160520ec590003u&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://montsame.mn/en/read/12959, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.pressreader.com/mongolia/the-ub-post/20170503/281732679386676, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: China Ministry of Commerce, Government Agency
title: China pledges 30 million CNY in cyclone relief to Vanuatu
description: On March 18, 2015, China's Ministry of Commerce pledged to provide 30 million yuan (4.87 million U.S. dollars) worth of relief supplies to cyclone-hit Vanuatu. Supplies would including tents, food, and power generators will be delivered by charter flight. On March 22, 2015, the first Chinese charted plane carrying 260 sets of tents arrived in the International Bauerfield Airport of Port Vila. From 22 March to 2 April, five Chinese chartered planes carried to Port Vila altogether 35 tons of rice, 35 tons of noodle, 6.5 tons of cookies, 800 sets of tents, 200 pieces of tarpaulins and 220 generators. The last two planes arrived on April 2. Yet the actual value of good delivered is unclear.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020150318eb3i004mr&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PARALL0020150325eb3p0005d&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PARALL0020150402eb41000mr&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://reliefweb.int/report/vanuatu/foreign-ministry-spokesperson-hong-leis-remarks-chinese-governments-latest-disaster, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; https://reliefweb.int/report/vanuatu/china-pledges-support-cyclone-hit-vanuatu, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.ibtimes.com/vanuatu-cyclone-pam-aid-china-pledges-48-million-worth-supplies-ministry-says-1850954, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.ibtimes.com/vanuatu-cyclone-pam-aid-china-pledges-48-million-worth-supplies-ministry-says-1850954, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/wjb_663304/zwjg_665342/zwbd_665378/t1259010.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/wjb_663304/zwjg_665342/zwbd_665378/t1259010.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

contacts: Joe Natuman, Vanuatu Prime Minister; James Bule, Minister of Climate Change Adaption and Geo-hazards; Xie Bohua, Chinese Ambassador; Osnat Lubrani, UN Humanitarian Coordinator for Vanuatu

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation (CCECC), State-owned Company
title: China provides Vt 3 billion grant for construction of sports complex in Vanuatu
description: In September 2014, China agreed to assist Vanuatu in its hosting of the 2017 Pacific Mini Games. China announced it would construct and cover the costs for the new Korman Stadium Complex, which would include the demolition of the current complex, construction of a gymnasium with a seating capacity of 1,000 people, renovation of the existing grandstand (capacity for 3,000 people) and drainage ditches and the tracks, as well as the construction of two swimming pools, four beach volleyball courts, four tennis courts, one basketball court, changing room for cricket players and renovation of the archery range. The project cost approximately Vt 3 billion ($27.98 million). Construction began in June 2016, and the stadium was handed over on October 30, 2017. In addition to this aid, China trained 190 Vanuatu athletes for 5 months in China, providing training and competition equipment. China also sent 13 coaches to in Port Vila to boost training to Vanuatu athletes.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PACN000020161123ecbm0005o&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://dailypost.vu/vanuatu_sports/new-stadium-opens/article_755d75b4-e55a-5c01-abbe-c35263d4bbbf.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://dailypost.vu/vanuatu_sports/construction-of-pacific-mini-games-facilities-advances/article_b0bad3e9-cf46-5016-a06e-c468d7496808.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://vanuatuindependent.com/2017/10/30/vanuatus-pacific-mini-games-complex-handed-over/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://dailypost.vu/news/china-has-done-a-lot-to-help-vanuatu-host-pacific/article_e2602d58-3b09-5944-b0fb-69ce04402761.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://websites.sportstg.com/get_file.cgi?id=3216648, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://dailypost.vu/vanuatu_sports/chinese-company-committed-to-completing-korman-stadium-before-mini-games/article_9bf33e7c-42d7-5673-a27e-bb0ff7e0c185.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=422212, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://dailypost.vu/news/china-assisting-vanuatu-build-sports-facilities-for-mini-games/article_96006945-8074-5773-9e20-dce5d6c913da.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Chinese government supports Popua Road upgrade in Tonga
description: STAFF_NOTE: Difficult to find articles beyond the Tonga Government press release regarding the ground breaking ceremony. Unclear what form Chinese 'support' comes in, although it seems likely that this support is financial in nature. Flow type is unclear. On 28 July 2015, the construction began on the Chinese-supported Popua Road Upgrade project in Tonga. The project aims to improve the road condition of Popua coastal area and protect the locals from the high level of sea water. The road for upgrading is about 300 meters long.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PARALL0020150728eb7r0004g&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://mic.gov.to/news-today/press-releases/5498-ground-breaking-for-china-aid-popua-road-upgrade-project, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Chinese government funds reconstruction of a dormitory on Uiha island in Tonga
description: STAFF_NOTE: Difficult to find articles beyond the initial announcement of funding. One article from Matangi, however, indicates completion of the project with Chinese funding and includes a photo of the completed dorm building in Pangai. It is unclear whether or not China funded the entire 70,000 pa'anga project. Flow type also unclear. On 2 September 2015, the Embassy of the People’s Republic of China in the Kingdom of Tonga announced that it would provide financial assistance for the reconstruction of the dormitory in Pangai for the students from ‘Uiha island in Ha’apai. The dormitory was seriously damaged during Cyclone Ian in January 2014. The estimated cost for the construction is 70,000 pa’anga. The construction is expected to start later in September 2015 and finish in December 2015.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PARALL0020150902eb920002x&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://matangitonga.to/2015/12/28/promote-cooperation-enhance-development-and-share-prosperity, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mic.gov.to/news-today/press-releases/5569-china-aid-uiha-student-dormitory-reconstruction, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China funds Eua Water Supply Project in Tonga
description: On 11 January 2016, the Tongan village of Houma celebrated the completion of the Chinese-funded water supply project in 'Eua. The project includes a new solar pump to bring spring water from Vai ‘a Hina (a spring in the region) up to the 160-meter cliff in the north of 'Eua and then transfer the water to more than 50 houses in Houma village. The project started in mid-October of 2015 and finished one week before Christmas. This project was worth over TOP100,000. The contractor was Mele Anitema Tonga Services. According to the estimate by the engineer, the flow of the spring is 5 liters per second.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PARALL0020151229ebct0003f&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PARALL0020160114ec1c00077&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.mic.gov.to/news-today/press-releases/5729-meteorological-brief-no-2-on-severe-tropical-cyclone-qulaq, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.looptonga.com/tonga-news/people-%E2%80%98eua-continue-get-assistance-government-china-50324, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/mfa_eng/wjb_663304/zwjg_665342/zwbd_665378/t1331269.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China assists Tonga with the creation of a sports complex for the 2019 Pacific Games (possible link to project ID #49235)
description: STAFF_NOTE: It is unclear what effect the government's decision to cancel hosting the 2019 Pacific Games will have on the foreign funding earmarked for the games. A grant aid agreement signed on 22 November 2015 between China and Tonga also included mention of funding for the development of sports facilities in Tonga for the 2019 Pacific Games (see project ID #49235), and it is unclear whether this funding amount relates to this project. On 20 April 2017 the Chinese government agreed to fund a US$24.8 million sports complex at Tonga High School for the 2019 Pacific Games after signing an implementation agreement with the Tonga government the week before. This complex would include an indoor gymnasium, one outdoor rugby field, four outdoor netball courts, an aquatics center, a lawn bowling field, and supporting facilities with a total area of 9,180 meters. The sports complex preparatory works were scheduled for August 2017, with construction expected to start in October 2017 and to be completed by May 2019. However, Tonga decided in May 2017 to cancel hosting the games, but China still agreed to fund the complex. Earlier, on 14 December 2016, the Chinese government had agreed to give aid to Tonga for the implementation of this same project. The amount of the Chinese funding and the cost of the project had not been released at that time. A grant aid agreement signed on 22 November 2015 between China and Tonga also included mention of funding for the development of sports facilities in Tonga for the 2019 Pacific Games (see project ID #49235), and it is unclear whether this funding amount relates to this project.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=RNZINT0020160503ec5300107&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=NANLEB0020161219eccj00096&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PARALL0020161219ecci0007i&cat=a&ep=ASE, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://matangitonga.to/2017/05/17/govt-officially-cancels-2019-pacific-games-tonga, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pireport.org/articles/2016/12/20/china-build-tonga-high-school-sports-complex, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/329139/sport-china-to-fund-sports-complex-in-tonga-for-pacific-games, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://kanivatonga.nz/2017/05/tonga-withdraws-from-hosting-pacific-games-2019-citing-world-bank-advice/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://nukualofatimes.tbu.to/?p=1909, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://nukualofatimes.tbu.to/?p=1909, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.pireport.org/articles/2017/03/26/chinese-design-team-tonga-finalize-plans-2019-pacific-games-complex, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://to.chineseembassy.org/eng/sgxw/t1425079.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://matangitonga.to/2017/05/18/china-nz-and-australia-honour-commitments-sporting-facilities, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Chinese and Tongan governments jointly commission Campus Road Upgrade Project of Tupou College in Tonga
description: STAFF_NOTE: Unclear how much of the 1 million TOP funding is provided from China. Flow type is also unclear. The implementing organization is unspecified. In May 2016, the Chinese government and Tongan government jointly commissioned the Campus Road Upgrade Project of Tupou College. The project would pave most roads inside the campus including the road to bush area. The cost of the project is around 1 million TOP and it is planned to be finished before the celebration of the 150th anniversary of Tupou College in June 2016.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Chinese Government provides 40,000 TOP to Tonga for the creation of Fua'amotu road
description: In March 2016, the Chinese government funded the creation of a new road in Fua'amotu in collaboration with Tongan Ministry of Infrastructure and local community in Fua’amotu. China would provide 40,000 Pa’anga for the diesel and professional works for the project. The new road is adjacent to Scenic Hotel near the Fua'amotu airport. This Chinese government-funded project officially started on 23 March 2016. STAFF_NOTE: Appears to be grant, but information cannot be found to confirm.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Chinese government donates seven ambulances and medical supplies worth 3 million yuan to Laos to support unexploded ordnance (UXO)
description: On April 2, 2015, the Chinese government donated seven ambulances and medical supplies worth 3 million yuan (about 480,000 U.S. dollars) in support of unexploded ordnance (UXO) to Laos. The ambulances will be allocated to provincial hospitals that deal with the majority of the nation's UXO casualties, as well as to the army's UXO Humanitarian Unit. On average, 300 people had been killed and countless more injured from accidents related to UXO in Laos each year from 1964 to 2008.

contacts: Guan Huabing, Chinese Ambassador to Laos

title: China donated 50,000 ringgit to Malaysia for flood-hit areas
description: On January 7, 2015, the Chinese Embassy in Malaysia recently also donated 50,000 ringgit (about 14,000 dollars) worth goods and materials to three states of Malaysia, of which, 30,000 ringgit (8,400 dollars) went to the worst-hit Terengganu, and 10,000 ringgit (2,800 dollars) to Kelantan and Pahang, respectively.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China committed 100 million yuan for building rehabilitation centers in the Philippines
description: On Oct 21, 2016, during Rodrigo Duerte's visit to Beijing, President Xi committed 100 million yuan, or about $15 million, for building rehabilitation centers to aid Mr. Duterte's brutal war on drugs.

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China gives P50 million to the Philippines after Typhoon Lawin (linked to #49287, #49290)
description: On Oct 24, 2016, the People's Republic of China announced it has donated millions to the Philippines after Super Typhoon Lawin (Haima). In a statement, the Chinese embassy said it donated P50 million to the Philippine government for the disaster relief of farmers and fishermen in the affected regions. This aid was delivered on Nov. 7, 2016. Along with this, China has also donated around P35 million to Philippine anti-disaster efforts on Nov. 22, 2016 (see project ID #49287), and the Red Cross Society of China provided humanitarian aid of $100,000 to the Philippines on Nov. 7, 2016 (see project ID #49290). The overall amount of aid from the Chinese side is about 90 million Pesos, the statement from Chinese embassy stated.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PHILNA0020161026ecap0004r&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://ph.china-embassy.org/eng/sgdt/t1408254.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.rappler.com/nation/150213-china-donates-millions-philippines-typhoon-lawin, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/10/25/1637199/china-donates-p90m-aid-philippines-typhoon-relief, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/10/25/16/china-donates-aid-to-ph-after-lawin, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://reliefweb.int/report/philippines/china-donates-p35-million-dswd-recovery-efforts-calamity-stricken-area, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/10/25/ph-receives-disaster-aid-from-china.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China commits P35 million to anti-disaster efforts in the Philippines after Typhoon Lawin (linked to #49284, #49290)
description: On Oct 24, 2016, the People's Republic of China announced it has donated millions to the Philippines after Super Typhoon Lawin (Haima). The Chinese Government committed 35 millions Pesos to the Philippine anti-disaster efforts. The People’s Republic of China gave the cash donation worth P35 million on Nov. 22, 2016 through the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) to help fund recovery and rehabilitation efforts of the Department for calamity-affected communities. In a simple turnover ceremony at the DSWD Central Office in Batasan, Quezon City, DSWD Secretary Judy M. Taguiwalo received the cash donation from Honorable He Xiangqi, Charge d’ Affaires of the Embassy of China in the Philippines. The Chinese Embassy in the Philippines donated an aid of 50 million Pesos to the Philippine Government, for the disaster relief of farmers and fishermen in the affected regions (see project ID #49284). The Red Cross Society of China also provided humanitarian aid of USD 100,000 to the Philippines (see project ID #49290). This aid was donated on Nov. 7, 2016. The overall amount of aid from the Chinese side is about 90 million Pesos, the statement from Chinese embassy stated.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=PHILNA0020161026ecap0004r&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://ph.china-embassy.org/eng/sgdt/t1408254.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.rappler.com/nation/150213-china-donates-millions-philippines-typhoon-lawin, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/10/25/1637199/china-donates-p90m-aid-philippines-typhoon-relief, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/10/25/16/china-donates-aid-to-ph-after-lawin, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://reliefweb.int/report/philippines/china-donates-p35-million-dswd-recovery-efforts-calamity-stricken-area, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/10/25/ph-receives-disaster-aid-from-china.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Export-Import Bank of China, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: China Communications Construction Company (CCCC), State-owned Company
title: EXIM Bank of China Funds Rail Construction in Malaysia
description: In November 2016, it was announced that China EXIM Bank would fund 85% of a rail project in Malaysia as part of the Belt and Road Initiative. The soft loan will fund 85% of the RM 55 billion project with 3.25 % interest, with a seven year moratorium. The rest will be financed through a bond program managed by local Malaysian banks. Malaysia will award the contract for the $13.1 billion USD (55 billion ringgit), over-600 km (most sources claim 688 km) line to China Communication Construction Company (CCCC). The engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contract and a financing framework will be signed during an upcoming visit of Prime Minister Najib. The Kuala Lumpur-Kelantan will be the third involvement of China firms in major projects in Malaysia. It will be called the East Coast Rail Link or ECRL and will run from Kuala Lumpur, passing through Pahang, Terengganu, and Kelantan states before ending in Tumpat, north of the Kelantan capital of Kota Baru. As of August 9, 2017, work on the ECRL had begun and was slated to finish in 2024. The ECRL is expected to create 80,000 jobs and carry 5.4 million passengers annually by 2030.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=STIMES0020161031ecb1003ib&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/najib-urges-china-to-complete-east-coast-rail-link-before-2024-9108022, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://news.mongabay.com/2017/08/malaysias-east-coast-rail-link-a-double-edged-sword-for-environment-wildlife/, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy; http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/east-coast-rail-link-malaysia-touts-rail-trade-route-as-rival-to-singapore, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.railway-technology.com/news/newsconstruction-starts-on-malaysias-13bn-east-coast-rail-link-project-5899707, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.railway-technology.com/features/featurechina-turns-malaysias-east-coast-rail-link-into-reality-5938409/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/china-set-to-build-finance-malaysia-s-east-coast-rail-line-proje-7766916, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.thesundaily.my/news/2017/08/09/ecrl-project-game-changer-malaysia-pm-najib-updated-0, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.reuters.com/article/us-malaysia-china-railway/hard-pedaling-soft-power-china-helps-launch-13-billion-belt-and-road-rail-project-in-malaysia-idUSKBN1AP12Y, Media Report, including Wikileaks

description: On 1 September 2016, the Chinese Embassy in Myanmar and the Ruili Municipality of China's Yunnan province donated 100 million kyats to Myanmar for the renovation of quake-damaged pagodas in Bagan. Additionally, Chinese Ambassador Hong Liang said that China would send a team of experts to Myanmar to help renovate the damaged pagodas in Bagan.

title: China donated 800,000 PHP worth of rescue equipment to the Philippines (linked with #49328 and #49329)
description: On October 2, 2015, Chinese Ambassador Zhao Jianhua visited Tacloban City, Leyte to personally assess recovery efforts in areas ravaged by super typhoon 'Yolanda' and donated P800,000 worth of rescue equipment. According to the Chinese Embassy in Manila, the donation is composed of safety helmets, life preservers, extrication equipment and first-aid kits which were turned over to Tacloban City rescue teams and units. description: On October 2, 2015, the Chinese government donated over 500 prefabricated houses to the Philippines, which then served as schools for the children in the area hit by typhoon Yolanda. This project is the third installment of Chinese aid after the storm (linked with #49327 and #49328).

title: China provides $50 million loan to Timor-Leste for drainage system upgrade
description: On December 18, 2015, Timor-Leste signed a concessional loan of $50 million from China EXIM Bank to upgrade Dili’s drainage system. The agreement allows Timor-Leste to have access to a concessional loan with a value of US$ 50 million, with an interest rate of 2% per year over 20 years with a grace period of 5 years with 20 year maturity.

description: In 2016, China loaned Cambodia $40.8 million to rehabilitate 38.9 km of National Road No. 51. The 12-meter-wide road connects the National Road 5 to the National Road 4. The China Road and Bridge Corporation will work on the project, which began in March 2017; it is expected to be completed in March 2020.
sources: https://data.opendevelopmentmekong.net/dataset/8b056306-0cd1-4b71-8361-65da79adcfd0/resource/37398c0b-74cc-4bb8-a7cb-cc0491059706/download/IRITWGOverviewoftheTransportInfrastructureSectorintheKingdomofCambodia2015.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.cambodiadaily.com/news/pm-wants-chinese-support-for-new-ring-road-126203/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.realestate.com.kh/news/infrastructure-xi-jinpings-hangover-3-road-and-bridge-projects-will-begin-in-2017/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.akp.gov.kh/?p=84826, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-03/14/c_136127436.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks
donor_agencies: China Road and Bridge Corporation, State-owned Company

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China loans Cambodia $130 million USD for the construction of National Road 60B
description: In 2015, China loaned Cambodia 130 million USD for the construction of National Road No. 60B. The road will stretch 141.67 kilometers from Kapo to Kampong Thma in the Mekong region and includes a bridge. The term and conditions of the loan are unknown.
sources: https://data.opendevelopmentmekong.net/dataset/8b056306-0cd1-4b71-8361-65da79adcfd0/resource/37398c0b-74cc-4bb8-a7cb-cc0491059706/download/IRITWGOverviewoftheTransportInfrastructureSectorintheKingdomofCambodia2015.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.eria.org/ERIA-RPR-FY2014-04.pdf, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China loans Cambodia $100 million USD for construction of National Road 64C
description: In 2011, China loaned Cambodia 100 million USD for the construction of the National Road 64C. The road stretches 132 km from Tbaeng Meanchey to Thearaborivat. Although the road is identified as a prospective project by an Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia (ERIA) report there are no sources beyond the 2015 Cambodian government report. Term and conditions of the loan are unknown.
sources: https://data.opendevelopmentmekong.net/dataset/8b056306-0cd1-4b71-8361-65da79adcfd0/resource/37398c0b-74cc-4bb8-a7cb-cc0491059706/download/IRITWGOverviewoftheTransportInfrastructureSectorintheKingdomofCambodia2015.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.eria.org/publications/research_project_reports/images/pdf/y2009/no7-1/Chapter6.pdf, Other Official Source (non-Donor, non-Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China constructs government building for Tonga
description: On August 25th, 2015, the groundbreaking ceremony for the construction of a government building called St. Georges Palace for Tonga. The project was originally initiated by King George IV in 2010, when the Chinese government donated TP$20 million for its construction. The Chinese Northeast Architectural Design and Research Institute Co. Ltd worked on the design for the building. The building is being constructed in Pangai Si'i, Nuku'alofa, and will be four stories. It will house the Prime Minister's office, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and and the Ministry of Finance and National Planning. STAFF_NOTE: Discrepency in cost of project, most sources agree between 20-25 million, Amount in transaction is what was allocated by the Government of Tonga Budget Report in 2014-2015.
sources: http://to.chineseembassy.org/eng/sgxw/t1293041.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.finance.gov.to/sites/default/files/Budget%20Statement%202014-15%20English%20FINAL.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kanivatonga.nz/2015/08/st-georges-palace-design-revealed-at-todays-foundation-ceremony-at-pangai-sii-site/, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.defenseone.com/politics/2015/06/how-china-building-biggest-commercial-military-empire-history/114853/, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China donates $30k in humanitarian aid to Fiji due to Cyclone Mick
description: In December 2009, China donated $30,000 in aid to Fiji for relief efforts due to Cyclone Mick.
sources: http://fj.china-embassy.org/eng/xw/t646695.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.ndmo.gov.fj/images/AllDisasterReports/TC_Mick_Final_Report.jan10.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Yang Jiechi, Minister of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China; Ratu Inoke Kubuabola, Minister for Foreign Affairs, International Cooperation and Civil Aviation of the Republic of the Fiji Islands; Han Zhiqiang, Ambassador to Fiji

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: Fiji Red Cross Society, National NGO
title: Chinese government donates 50,000 USD through Red Cross to Fiji after Cyclone Tomas
description: STAFF_NOTE: Not to be confused with project ID #49526. On March 18, 2010, to help the disaster relief and rehabilitation effort of Fiji after Cyclone Tomas, the Chinese Government provided US$50,000.00 (FJ$96,000.00) emergency humanitarian aid through the Red Cross Society of China to the Fiji Red Cross Society.
sources: http://fj.china-embassy.org/eng/xw/t673720.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://reliefweb.int/report/fiji/fiji-china-cash-aid-hurricane-relief, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy
donor_agencies: Red Cross Society of China, Government Agency
recipient_agencies: Fiji Red Cross Society, National NGO
contacts: Han Zhiqiang, Ambassador to Fiji

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Chinese embassy donates FJ$50,000 to Fiji after Cyclone Tomas
description: STAFF_NOTE: Not to be confused with project ID #49524. On March 18, 2010, to help the disaster relief and rehabilitation effort of Fiji after Cyclone Tomas, the Chinese Embassy in Fiji donated FJ$50,000.00 to the Prime Minister's National Disaster Relief and Rehabilitation Fund. The donation was handed over to the Prime Minister's Office.
sources: http://fj.china-embassy.org/eng/xw/t673720.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://reliefweb.int/report/fiji/fiji-china-cash-aid-hurricane-relief, NGO/Civil Society/Advocacy
contacts: Han Zhiqiang, Ambassador to Fiji

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China grants Cambodia $48.3 million USD for National Road no. 258 in 2011
description: In 2011, China granted $48.3 million USD to Cambodia for construction of National Road no. 258. The project was completed in 2013. The road stretches 20 km from National Road no. 5 in Kob to O Beychoann. Other details about the grant are unknown.
sources: https://data.opendevelopmentmekong.net/dataset/8b056306-0cd1-4b71-8361-65da79adcfd0/resource/37398c0b-74cc-4bb8-a7cb-cc0491059706/download/IRITWGOverviewoftheTransportInfrastructureSectorintheKingdomofCambodia2015.pdf, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China Donates Sports Facilities to Samoa College
description: In 2015, as part of the establishment of sister school relationship between Hua Luogeng High School and Samoa College, Mayor Mai Jiaomeng donated sports facilities to Samoa College. The Huizhou municipal government delegation led by Mayor Mai Jiaomeng visited Samoa College on November 11, 2015 and signed an MOU of sister school relationship between Huan Luogeng High School and Samoa College. Chinese Ambassador Wang Xuefeng and officials from Minister of Education of Samoa graced the ceremony which was also attended by more than 700 people including teachers and students of Samoa College, diplomats from Economic and Commercial Department of Chinese Embassy and friends from local press.
sources: http://ws2.mofcom.gov.cn/article/bilateralcooperation/inbrief/201511/20151101195712.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ws2.mofcom.gov.cn/article/bilateralcooperation/inbrief/201511/20151101195712.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China Provided Grant for Construction of Loto Taumafai Society National Disability Centre
description: In 2011, the Chinese government decided to provide a grant of $12 million to the Samoan government to build the new Loto Taumafai Society National Disability Centre. The Centre will include eleven classrooms, necessary facilities, and an early intervention programme for 300 children. The complex will also involve a vocational workshop, a pool, computer rooms, gymnasium, dining hall, and a two-story office block. The Centre completion ceremony occurred on November 6, 2015.
sources: http://ws2.mofcom.gov.cn/article/bilateralcooperation/inbrief/201511/20151101195707.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201512/20151201218068.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://www.pireport.org/articles/2014/09/23/chinese-funded-disability-center-takes-shape-samoa, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: Shanghai Construction Group General Co., State-owned Company
title: China Provides Loan for Upgrade of Valeo International Airport In Samoa
description: On Nov.30th 2016, the first phase of the upgrading process for the Valeo International Airport in Samoa has been completed, which was funded by a preferential loan from China. The first phase consisted of a year of construction by Shanghai Construction Engineering, resulting in 7,000 square meters of airport departure terminals, jet fuel centers, parking lots and roads. The next phase of construction should result in an annual service capacity of 600,000 passengers, and should be implemented over the next year. The airport is expected to increase tourism and Samoa's international standards.
sources: http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201612/20161202029969.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201612/20161202029968.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
donor_agencies: Shanghai Construction Group General Co., State-owned Company

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Chinese government donates $1million to Cambodia in order to help flood victims
description: On Oct.31st, 2013, Chinese Ambassador to Cambodia Jianguo Bu met with Prime Minister Hun Sen and delivered the 1 million US dollar donation for all the flood victims in Cambodia. China sincerely hope that this donation could partly help Cambodians recover from the disaster and rebuild destroyed homes. The donation was delivered separately in cash and supplies continuously from 2013 to 2014.
sources: http://cb.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201311/20131100376707.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://reliefweb.int/report/cambodia/more-chinese-humanitarian-aid-reaches-cambodia, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
implementing_agencies: Guangdong Foreign Construction Co., Ltd (GDFC), Private Sector
title: Chinese-donated Cambodian House of Senate is officially finished construction
description: On Jan 20th, 2014, Chinese Ambassador to Cambodia Jianguo Bu and Deputy Chairman of the Cambodian Senate Say Chhum as well as all Cambodian senators attended the completion ceremony of the Chinese-donated Senate House. The new construction included three three-level buildings and were built intended to keep the friendly cooperation and neighbor country relationship between Chinese and Cambodian legislation departments.
sources: http://cb.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201401/20140100469036.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
donor_agencies: Guangdong Foreign Construction Co., Ltd (GDFC), Private Sector
contacts: Jianguo Bu, Chinese Ambassador to Cambodia; Say Chhum, Deputy Chairman of the Cambodian Senate

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China donates 7 billion kyat in relief aid to Myanmar
description: In March 2016, China donated the first batch of 7 billion kyat in relief aid to Myanmar due to severe flooding. The aid is to restore electricity to damaged areas. The articles also mentions that two other batches of donation would be delivered in April and June.
sources: http://mm.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/201603/20160301285950.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Completion ceremony of China-loaned Laos National Electric Corporation power dispatching center I was held
description: On September 11th, 2013, the completion ceremony of China-loaned Laos National Electric Corporation power dispatching center I was held. The project connected the power dispatching center with the corporation's 16 stations through optical fiber.
sources: http://la.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201309/20130900308209.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://finance.ifeng.com/a/20130917/10703264_0.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.tdworld.com/overhead-transmission/laos-expands-grid, Media Report, including Wikileaks

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China donates supplies to Tonga
description: On March 21, 2003, China donated several supplies to Tonga, including tents and asphalt felt cloth. The ceremony was held in Nuku'a lofa, Tonga. Chinese Ambassador Shanhai Gao and Tonga Deputy Vice Prime Minister both attended the ceremony.
sources: http://to.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/200303/20030300076526.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Shanhai Gao, Chinese Ambassador to Tonga

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China builds technical agriculture center in Tonga
description: On November 15, 2003 China opened the Aidang Demonstration Farm in Tonga, an agricultural training center. Nine major categories of 64 Chinese varieties of vegetables were planted; Tonga technical staff conducted 27 lecture trainings which consisted of techniques on nursery, transplanting, irrigation to pruning, harvesting and other advanced management methods. Chinese Ambassador Shanhai Gao and Tonga Minister of Agriculture signed the exchanging certification, which marked the successful ending of this farm project. On Nov.10th, 2004, the farm was handed over to the Tongan government.
sources: http://to.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/200411/20041100303873.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
contacts: Shanhai Gao, Chinese Ambassador to Tonga

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: Opening ceremony of China-donated Tonga Varney Health Center was held
description: On Nov.10th, 2011, the opening ceremony of China-donated Tonga Varney Health Center was held. Togan Minister of Health and Minister of Lands along with representatives from both governments and WHO all attended the ceremony.
sources: http://to.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201111/20111107824100.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China grants $8.5 million in aid to Cook Islands
description: In April 2004, China funded $15 million to Cook Islands for the construction of the Avarua courthouse, police national headquarters and a sports center. The Avarua (Rarotonga) courthouse costs about $4.8 million and police headquarters costs $3.7 million. staff_note: Though there are multiple resources suggest that China grants $15 million, there were no further information about when and how the grant is used.
sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=BBCAPP0020040502e052002bd&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://books.google.com/books/about/Looking_North_Looking_South.html?id=KYQ6nw6AJ2YC, Academic Journal Article
contacts: Bo Xilai, Minister (China Ministry of Commerce)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China Builds Falule Primary School in Samoa
description: In 2013, Shanghai Construction began building the Falule primary school in Samoa. The building was handed over to Samoa on January 4th, 2014, and contains 8 classrooms, a library, a computer room, a music room, and an activities hall. It was equipped with computers and an organ, as well as other multi-media and teaching equipment. STAFF_NOTE: School name may be different due to translation errors.
sources: http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201401/20140100476950.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201603/20160301286600.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China grant two Samoan schools in Levao and Sapapali
description: China granted two schools located in Valeo and Sappali, and held a completion ceremony.
sources: http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201311/20131100379444.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China Funded Samoan School Matautu Primary School
description: On March 5th, 2008, China signed an exchange of Memorandum regarding the reconstruction of Matautu Primary School in Samoa. Then, on July 8th, 2008, a design contract for the project was signed. The school was then completed and handed over to the Samoan people on January 8th, 2011. STAFF_NOTE: Name of the school may be different due to translation errors.
sources: http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/200803/20080305426434.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/200807/20080705663653.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201102/20110207389433.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Unspecified Chinese Government Institution, Government Agency
title: China funded a second rural elementary school in Samoa
description: In January, 2009, an elementary school named A-ai-lee in Samoa, funded by China, was initiated. According to further report from Chinese embassy in March, 2011, the school construction had been completed and transferred to Samoan government. According to the reports, this was the second elementary school China had constructed in Samoa, and until 2016 ten such schools have been completed in Samoa. This is part of the pledge the former Chinese Prime Minister, Wen Jiabao, had made at a UNESCO meeting in 2005, which stipulated that China would build 100 elementary schools in rural areas in developing countries.
sources: http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/200902/20090206024212.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ws.chineseembassy.org/chn/sgxw/t1388979.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://ws.mofcom.gov.cn/aarticle/ztdy/201103/20110307425159.html, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)

funding_agencies: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), State-owned Company
title: China contributes $160 million for tallest Indonesian building
description: The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Indonesia Branch) is providing $160 million in funding to China Sonangol/AnMed Media Investment Co for the construction of one of the tallest building complexes in Indonesia, with the intent of supporting Indonesia's infrastructure and construction project. The complex will contain twin buildings that stand 303 meters tall, and will house offices, businesses, and apartments. Indonesian President Zoco Widodo was present for the groundbreaking ceremony for the structure. The two towers, Indonesia-1 North and South towers, are expected to be complete in 2019.
sources: http://id.mofcom.gov.cn/article/sbmy/201508/20150801076183.shtml, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.chinagoabroad.com/en/market_review/china-sonangol-to-build-indonesia-s-tallest-towers, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://indonesia.sinchew.com.my/node/55749, Media Report, including Wikileaks
donor_agencies: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), State-owned Company
contacts: Shen Xiaoqi, Manager, Indonesia Branch (Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC))
